captions.text:
Have you ever daydreamed
about traveling through time,

perhaps fast forward in the centuries
and seeing the distant future?
Well, time travel is possible,
and what's more, it's already been done.
Meet Sergei Krikalev,

the greatest time traveler
in human history.
This Russian cosmonaut holds the record

for the most amount of time
spent orbiting our planet,

a total of 803 days,
9 hours, and 39 minutes.
During his stay in space,
he time traveled into his own future
by 0.02 seconds.
Traveling at 17,500 miles an hour,

he experienced an effect
known as time dilation,
and one day the same effect

might make significant time travel
to the future commonplace.

To see why moving faster through space
affects passage of time,
we need to go back to the 1880s,
when two American scientists,
Albert Michelson and Edward Morley,

were trying to measure the effect
of the Earth's movement around the Sun
on the speed of light.

When a beam of light was moving
in the same direction as the Earth,
they expected the light to travel faster.

And when the Earth was moving
in the opposite direction,
they expected it to go slower.
But they found something very curious.

The speed of light remained the same
no matter what the Earth was doing.

Two decades later,
Albert Einstein was thinking

about the consequences
of that never-changing speed of light.
And it was his conclusions,

formulated in the theory
of special relativity,

that opened the door
into the world of time travel.
Imagine a man named Jack,

standing in the middle
of a train carriage,
traveling at a steady speed.

Jack's bored and starts bouncing
a ball up and down.

What would Jill, standing on the platform,
see through the window
as the train whistles through?

Well, between Jack dropping the ball
and catching it again,

Jill would have seen him move
slightly further down the track,

resulting in her seeing the ball
follow a triangular path.

This means Jill sees the ball
travel further than Jack does
in the same time period.

And because speed
is distance divided by time,
Jill actually sees the ball move faster.

But what if Jack's bouncing ball
is replaced with two mirrors
which bounce a beam of light between them?
Jack still sees the beam dropping down

and Jill still sees the light beam
travel a longer distance,

except this time Jack and Jill
cannot disagree on the speed

because the speed of light
remains the same no matter what.

And if the speed is the same
while the distance is different,

this means the time taken
will be different as well.

Thus, time must tick at different rates
for people moving relative to each other.

Imagine that Jack and Jill
have highly accurate watches

that they synchronize
before Jack boards the train.

During the experiment,
Jack and Jill would each see
their own watch ticking normally.

But if they meet up again later
to compare watches,

less time would have
elapsed on Jack's watch,

balancing the fact that Jill saw
the light move further.
This idea may sound crazy,
but like any good scientific theory,
it can be tested.
In the 1970s, scientists boarded a plane
with some super-accurate atomic clocks

that were synchronized
with some others left on the ground.

After the plane had
flown around the world,

the clocks on board
showed a different time
from those left behind.

Of course, at the speed
of trains and planes,
the effect is minuscule.

But the faster you go,
the more time dilates.

For astronauts orbiting
the Earth for 800 days,
it starts to add up.

But what affects humans
also affects machines.

Satellites of the global
positioning system
are also hurdling around the Earth
at thousands of miles an hour.
So, time dilation kicks in here, too.

In fact, their speed causes
the atomic clocks on board
to disagree with clocks on the ground
by seven millionths of a second daily.
Left uncorrected,
this would cause GPS to lose accuracy
by a few kilometers each day.

So, what does all this have
to do with time travel
to the far, distant future?

Well, the faster you go,
the greater the effect of time dilation.
If you could travel really close
to the speed of light, say 99.9999%,
on a round-trip through space
for what seemed to you like ten years,
you'd actually return to Earth
around the year 9000.

Who knows what you'd see
when you returned?!
Humanity merged with machines,

extinct due to climate change
or asteroid impact,
or inhabiting a permanent colony on Mars.
But the trouble is,

getting heavy things like people,
not to mention space ships,

up to such speeds requires
unimaginable amounts of energy.

It already takes enormous
particle accelerators
like the Large Hadron Collider

to accelerate tiny subatomic particles
to close to light speed.

But one day, if we can develop the tools
to accelerate ourselves to similar speeds,
then we may regularly send time travelers
into the future,

bringing with them tales
of a long, forgotten past.

title: Is time travel possible? - Colin Stuart

I actually had this idea a while ago for an experiment to discover if life 
can emerge on its own, given enough time, from non-living matter. The idea 
is to send off a spaceship filled with inert organic material at 
99.99999999999999999% the speed of light (and I calculated this out a while 
ago, so I may be mis-remembering the exact number), to cause the contents 
to experience a billion years of evolution in about a day of our time.﻿

comments.author: Flint Sheep

comments.text:
I've always found that ball experiment silly. Jack is only measuring 
distance traveled in one dimension, on the x axis, whereas Jill is 
measuring in two dimensions, on the x and y axis. In other words, Jack is 
measuring from his hand to the floor whereas Jill is measuring his hand to 
the floor + the distance the train has traveled in the time the ball has 
left his hand and reached the floor. Now if Jack is bouncing the ball at an 
angle, then you have to figure in for a third dimension, z and the ball 
would have traveled even further. It's not time travel. It's just bad math.﻿

comments.text:
IMO, time travel is not possible an will never be, and i have 2 solid 
arguments/paradoxes to prove it.

1: Time travel is and will never be possible because whe have never seen 
someone of the future. Think about it: if time travel WAS possible, in some 
point in the future someone would have traveled back in time and find 
himself in the era whe live in now, prehaps someone might have traveled to 
the time i started writing this comment to prove me it DOES exist, but that 
didn't happen cuz i already posted it. And because of this argument. I can 
not only say it doesn't exist now, but it will absoluteley NEVER EVER EVER 
EVER exist..
 
On to my second point. If the argument above is false and time travel will 
ever exist.It will be a funny scenario/paradox.
 If you would want to travel back in time and plan on getting back to 
you're own time aswell....every time you are about to step in to the "time 
portal", if you look back, you'll see a copy of yourself running in to do 
the same thing, why? Cuz if you go back in time and after a while travel 
back to the momment before you stepped in to the portal. You would again 
see yourself but this time infront of the portal. And the "new" copy of you 
will look back at you...remember? You did the same thing when you 
"originaly" went into the portal yourself, not youre copy. You looked back 
and saw you're "copy" but now technicaly you are the copy since you are the 
one behind "yourself". So every time basicaly if you are in front of a time 
portal you'll constantly see yourself running to the portal in a endless 
loop. If you didn't understand any of the sh*t i wrote in this long ass 
comment: re-read it, if you still dont, eat a 5 dollar foot long at Subway 
and try again.

PS: This is only my theory, im 11 years old and i have my thougts too you 
know.
PPS: Im realy 11 years old﻿

comments.text:
Time travel violates the First Law of Thermodynamics: Conservation of 
Energy.  You can't make energy or matter disappear from "this" universe and 
re-appear in another.  This would upset the sum balance of energy in TWO 
universes and/or two time frames of the same universe.   Sorry, but, it's 
the law.  Time travel is total fantasy.  If the grandfather paradox wasn't 
enough for you, breaking the 1st Law of Thermodynamics should cinch the 
deal.﻿

comments.text:
Einstein's 1905 false constant-speed-of-light postulate was not supported 
by the Michelson-Morley experiment. Actually, in 1887 (prior to FitzGerald 
and Lorenz advancing the ad hoc length contraction hypothesis) the 
Michelson-Morley experiment unequivocally confirmed the variable speed of 
light predicted by Newton's emission theory of light and refuted the 
constant (independent of the speed of the light source) speed of light 
predicted by the ether theory:

http://www.philoscience.unibe.ch/documents/kursarchiv/SS07/Norton.pdf 
 John Norton: "These efforts were long misled by an exaggeration of the 
importance of one experiment, the Michelson-Morley experiment, even though 
Einstein later had trouble recalling if he even knew of the experiment 
prior to his 1905 paper. This one experiment, in isolation, has little 
force. Its null result happened to be fully compatible with Newton's own 
emission theory of light. Located in the context of late 19th century 
electrodynamics when ether-based, wave theories of light predominated, 
however, it presented a serious problem that exercised the greatest 
theoretician of the day."

http://philsci-archive.pitt.edu/1743/2/Norton.pdf 
 John Norton: "In addition to his work as editor of the Einstein papers in 
finding source material, Stachel assembled the many small clues that reveal 
Einstein's serious consideration of an emission theory of light; and he 
gave us the crucial insight that Einstein regarded the Michelson-Morley 
experiment as evidence for the principle of relativity, whereas later 
writers almost universally use it as support for the light postulate of 
special relativity. Even today, this point needs emphasis. The 
Michelson-Morley experiment is fully compatible with an emission theory of 
light that CONTRADICTS THE LIGHT POSTULATE."

http://books.google.com/books?id=JokgnS1JtmMC 
 Relativity and Its Roots, Banesh Hoffmann, p.92: "There are various 
remarks to be made about this second principle. For instance, if it is so 
obvious, how could it turn out to be part of a revolution - especially when 
the first principle is also a natural one? Moreover, if light consists of 
particles, as Einstein had suggested in his paper submitted just thirteen 
weeks before this one, the second principle seems absurd: A stone thrown 
from a speeding train can do far more damage than one thrown from a train 
at rest; the speed of the particle is not independent of the motion of the 
object emitting it. And if we take light to consist of particles and assume 
that these particles obey Newton's laws, they will conform to Newtonian 
relativity and thus automatically account for the null result of the 
Michelson-Morley experiment without recourse to contracting lengths, local 
time, or Lorentz transformations. Yet, as we have seen, Einstein resisted 
the temptation to account for the null result in terms of particles of 
light and simple, familiar Newtonian ideas, and introduced as his second 
postulate something that was more or less obvious when thought of in terms 
of waves in an ether. If it was so obvious, though, why did he need to 
state it as a principle? Because, having taken from the idea of light waves 
in the ether the one aspect that he needed, he declared early in his paper, 
to quote his own words, that "the introduction of a 'luminiferous ether' 
will prove to be superfluous."

http://www.amazon.com/QED-Strange-Theory-Light-Matter/dp/0691024170 
 Richard Feynman, "QED: The strange theory of light and matter", p. 15: "I 
want to emphasize that light comes in this form - particles. It is very 
important to know that light behaves like particles, especially for those 
of you who have gone to school, where you probably learned something about 
light behaving like waves. I'm telling you the way it does behave - like 
particles. You might say that it's just the photomultiplier that detects 
light as particles, but no, every instrument that has been designed to be 
sensitive enough to detect weak light has always ended up discovering the 
same thing: light is made of particles."﻿

comments.text:
Time travel is a staple of science fiction stories, but is it actually 
possible?
It turns out there is a way of bending time, an exciting possibility 
suggested by Albert Einstein when he discovered special relativity over one 
hundred years ago.

Colin Stuart imagines where (or, when) this fascinating phenomenon, time 
dilation, may one day take us.﻿

comments.author: lazar vladisavljevic

comments.text:
+lazar vladisavljevic It seems like you're thinking of this as a "trick" to 
slow down your watch, but it isn't like that. Time itself becomes warped, 
so everything that happens around you would go on at the usual speed from 
your own perspective (including your heartbeat). Think of it like walking 
up a set of stairs vs. walking up a moving escalator - your walking speed 
from your perspective is the same in both cases, but someone watching would 
see your speed on the escalator as being much faster.

As for "how is it possible"... that's the mystery. With the escalator 
example, it's obvious that the added speed of the escalator is what makes 
your speed faster, but I don't think it is well understood why high speeds 
have the effect that they do on time.
comments.author: Chandra McCann

comments.text:
Well explained :) but let's go back to the aging and heartbeats, would your 
body know that your time is changed?

And that guy that went 0.02 seconds into the future is he that much in 
front of us(I know he's not, but anyway...)?

One more thing, If clocks keep ticking at the same rate, than how is it 
possible that they do not match? If they are not ticking at the same rate, 
would you notice that with your body? Or it is just a clock trick?

I think that's the right question...Thanks!
comments.author: lazar vladisavljevic

comments.text:
+lazar vladisavljevic yes and no, it will tick at the same speed, but time 
outside will go faster. 
if there was a huge bell on earth that went of once an hour, and you could 
'hear it' inside the 'time machine' IT would beat faster. for everything 
outside the 'time machine' would happen at a faster pace. so for someone on 
the outside it would seem like everything inside would slow down. 
time is simply relative to your current speed, (have you heard that gravity 
on earth is not the same strength everywhere? if you went on top of Mouth 
Everest, you'd be lighter. it's kinda the same.)

though this type of space-time messes up our brains, we are used to time as 
a constant. but we wouldn't notice if time passed by faster. f.eks: if the 
earth speed up its speed around the sun, our time relative to the outside 
would slow down. but time would pass by on earth the same. (except the 
speed of a year)

comments.author: kowdermeister

comments.text:
This time dilation just doesn't make sense to me. It doesn't seem to hold 
up in every skeptical scenario I can think of. Like, what if we used light 
to pass data back and forth between Mars and Earth. Time dilation would 
suggest that this data, no matter its direction, arrives at its destination 
long before either receiver has had time to acknowledge it. That's like 
saying if I write you a letter and send it via snail mail on a 3 day 
delivery, it somehow arrives in your mailbox on day 2 but you can't see it, 
or even know it's there, until day 3.

The reason is because I am experiencing a different timeline than the 
message is experiencing. So while the message may have only took 48 hours 
to get to me, I only see it on or after hour 72.  Something about that just 
doesn't sit well with my brain.﻿
comments.author: itcanbecheezcaketime

comments.text:
+itcanbecheezcaketime Time is not absolute. Time is invariant to Lorentz 
transformation.
comments.author: TheLeftLibertarianAtheist

comments.text:
That's just how time relativity works.

It is a subject that doesn't sound logical when you first hear/read about 
it (well neither does an infinitely expanding universe), but it makes a lot 
of sense once you learn about the laws of the universe and how things works 
outside our little planet we call Earth.
comments.author: Delfinition

comments.text: be flexible with your thinking and be open minded to theories?
comments.author: BamItsHazel

comments.text:
+Luis Diaz  That's what doesn't make sense to me. It doesn't seem logical. 
The idea that time is relative to the observer just doesn't sit well with 
me because it implies that time is subjective and not the ultimate unifier 
of all things. I realize the scientific consensus says otherwise, but I 
still have trouble accepting it. The idea that light could travel from some 
distant source to Earth instantaneously, yet years would go by for those on 
Earth seems like magical thinking and an irrational explanation. How could 
something literally arrive here instantly yet us not know about it for 
years to come? Clearly I'm still confused. But don't get me wrong, I 
comprehend the explanation that you and many others have provided, but it's 
that explanation that doesn't sit well with me. What seems logical in my 
head is that IF light could reach us instantaneously from some distant 
source, we would see it immediately because time is the ultimate unifier of 
all things, not something that is subjective.

If we're standing 100 feet apart and I point a laser in your eye, the time 
it takes for the light to reach your eye from where I'm standing is the 
same for both you and I. At least that's how I think, anyway. It's not 
literally instantaneous and it never could be.
comments.author: itcanbecheezcaketime

comments.text:
I think you're looking at it the wrong way.  There are 2 factors in your 
"letter/light data theory" that you haven't acknowledged in my opinion; 
Distance, and direction of time relative to the object moving.  Time 
dilation would not happen at point a)Earth or point b)Mars but at the 
distance between them.

If you greatly increase the distance you send this message, (say the 
receiver of this message is not on mars but on a planet 4 light years away 
from Earth, and its not data but a mailman with a letter moving at the 
speed of light) Relative to the mailman, they would arrive with the letter 
instantaneously. Yet, to you (on Earth) 4 years have passed for it to 
arrive at its destination.  

I think you're confused by how light is constant no matter the direction in 
time it flows, but thats only true to light not the observer.
comments.author: Luis Diaz

comments.text:

rotation, because if they don't they are wrong﻿
